instruction: Tell me about the BS Four-Year Degree Plan: Computer Science/Computer Science Option (ABET Accredited) at Missouri State University.
response:
This is a sample four-year plan for the ABET-accredited BS in Computer Science (Computer Science Option).

Key details:
• **Total Hours:** 120 credit hours
• **Components:** Includes Core/Major courses, Required Math/Science/GenEd courses, and a required Minor or Second Major (often satisfied by the Math minor).
• **Graduation Requirement:** Students must successfully complete the Computer Science Major Field Test (MFT).

**Resources:**
View the plan here: https://computerscience.missouristate.edu/Major/BS-Four-Year-Computer-Science.html

**Next Steps:**
This is a sample, so you should always meet with your advisor to plan your actual schedule.

metadata.topic: BS Four-Year Degree Plan: Computer Science/Computer Science Option (ABET Accredited)

instruction: What is the BS Four-Year Degree Plan: Computer Science/Computer Science Option (ABET Accredited) program at MSU?
response:
This is a 120-credit hour, ABET-accredited curriculum for the BS in Computer Science, designed to be completed in four years.

It focuses on foundational and advanced Computer Science concepts and includes:
• Specific General Education courses
• Math and Science requirements
• A mandatory Minor or Second Major (often satisfied by Math courses)

**Resources:**
See the sample schedule: https://computerscience.missouristate.edu/Major/BS-Four-Year-Computer-Science.html

**Next Steps:**
This is only a sample. You must meet with an advisor to confirm your schedule.

instruction: What are the graduation requirements for the BS Computer Science/Computer Science Option (ABET Accredited) at Missouri State University?
response:
Graduation requirements for the BS in Computer Science include:

• **Total Hours:** A minimum of 120 total credit hours.
• **Core Courses:** Successful completion of all major and General Education requirements.
• **Minor:** A minor or second major is required.
• **Exit Exam:** Successful completion of the Computer Science Major Field Test (MFT).

**Resources:**
See the full degree plan: https://computerscience.missouristate.edu/Major/BS-Four-Year-Computer-Science.html

**Next Steps:**
Meet with your advisor regularly to ensure you are on track to meet all requirements.

metadata.topic: BS Four-Year Degree Plan: Computer Science/Computer Science Option (ABET Accredited)

instruction: How many total credit hours are required for graduation with the BS in Computer Science?
response:
You need at least **120 total credit hours** to graduate with a BS in Computer Science.

**Additional Requirement:**
• At least 40 of these hours must be at the 300-level or above.

**Resources:**
This requirement is listed on the official department flowchart: https://www.cs.missouristate.edu

**Next Steps:**
Use the flowchart and your C-APP report to track your total hours and your upper-division hours.

metadata.topic: Total Credit Hour Requirement (Missouri State University)

instruction: Is there a test required to graduate with the Computer Science Option?
response:
Yes, successful completion of the **computer science major field test (MFT)** is required to graduate.

**Requirement:**
• You must achieve at least a score of 50th percentile.

**Resources:**
This is a requirement on the official degree flowchart: https://www.cs.missouristate.edu

**Next Steps:**
Speak to your advisor about when to schedule the MFT, which is typically done in your final year.

instruction: I have taken CSC 325. What courses does this unlock?
response:
After completing CSC 325 (Algorithms & Adv. Data Structures), you have fulfilled a key prerequisite for **CSC 450 (Software Engineering)**.

**Full Prerequisites for CSC 450:**
• CSC 325
• CSC 335 (Database Systems Concepts)
• CSC 360 (Operating Systems)

**Resources:**
See the course flow on the department flowchart: https://www.cs.missouristate.edu

**Next Steps:**
Ensure you have also taken CSC 335 and CSC 360 before registering for CSC 450.

response:
Based on the flowchart, if you have completed CSC 130, 131, 232, 244, and 333, here are your remaining core CS courses:

• **Remaining Core CS:**
  • CSC 325(3) Algorithms & Adv. Data Structures
  • CSC 335(3) Database Systems Concepts
  • CSC 360(3) Operating Systems
  • CSC 365(3) Internet Programming
  • CSC 388(3) Intro to Secure Computing
  • CSC 450(4) Software Engineering

instruction: What math courses are required for the Computer Science Option?
response:
The required math courses for the Computer Science Option are:

• **MTH 261(5):** Calculus I
• **MTH 280(5):** Calculus II
• **MTH 314(3):** Discrete Mathematics
• **MTH 315(3):** Algebraic Structures
• **MTH 345(3) or MTH 540(3):** Statistics or Statistical Theory

**Resources:**
See the full list on the CS flowchart: https://www.cs.missouristate.edu

**Next Steps:**
Note that MTH 261 is a prerequisite for MTH 280. Plan your schedule accordingly.

instruction: What are the science course requirements for the CS major?
response:
You must complete two science courses for the CS major:

• **Physics:** PHY 203(5) Found. of Physics I OR PHY 123(4) Intro to Physics I
• **Life Science:** BIO 121(4) OR BMS 110(3)

**Resources:**
These are listed on the CS flowchart: https://www.cs.missouristate.edu

**Next Steps:**
The flowchart notes that these courses may also count toward General Education requirements. Check your C-APP report to confirm.

instruction: How many CSC elective hours are needed?
response:
You must complete **9 hours** chosen from the approved CSC elective list.

**Key Restrictions:**
• No more than three hours can count from CSC 399.
• No more than three hours can count from CSC 596.

**Examples of Electives:**
• CSC 330: Intro to Data Science
• CSC 540: Intro. to Artificial Intelligence
• CSC 567: Mobile Computing Applications

**Resources:**
See the full list of elective options on the CS flowchart: https://www.cs.missouristate.edu

**Next Steps:**
Talk to your advisor about which electives best match your career goals.

instruction: List all the courses that a student needs to graduate with a Bachelor's of Computer Science.
response:
To graduate with the BS in Computer Science (Computer Science Option), you must complete the following:

• **Core CS Courses (13):**
  • CSC 130(3), CSC 131(4), CSC 232(4), CSC 244(3), CSC 325(3), CSC 333(2), CSC 335(3), CSC 360(3), CSC 365(3), CSC 388(3), CSC 450(4), CSC 482(2), CSC 565(3)
• **Math Courses (5):**
  • MTH 261(5), MTH 280(5), MTH 314(3) or MTH 315(3) or MTH 345(3) or MTH 540(3)
• **Science Courses (2):**
  • PHY 203(5) or PHY 123(4)
  • BIO 121(4) or BMS 110(3)
• **CS Electives:**
  • 9 hours from the approved list
• **General Education:**
  • All remaining GenEd requirements.

**Resources:**
See the full flowchart for visualization: https://www.cs.missouristate.edu

**Next Steps:**
You must also complete 120 total hours and pass the MFT exit exam.

metadata.topic: All Required Courses for BS in Computer Science (Missouri State University)

instruction: I have completed CSC 130, CSC 131, CSC 232, CSC 244, and CSC 335. What are the other courses I need to take to graduate?
response:
If you have completed CSC 130, 131, 232, 244, and 335, you still need the following courses:

• **Remaining Core CS:**
  • CSC 325(3), CSC 333(2), CSC 360(3), CSC 365(3), CSC 388(3), CSC 450(4), CSC 482(2), CSC 565(3)
• **Math Courses:**
  • MTH 261(5), MTH 280(5), MTH 314(3), MTH 315(3), MTH 345(3) or MTH 540(3)
• **Science Courses:**
  • PHY 203(5) or 123(4), and BIO 121(4) or BMS 110(3)
• **CS Electives:**
  • 9 hours
• **Other:**
  • Remaining GenEd, 120 total hours, and pass the MFT.

**Resources:**
Compare your progress with the CS flowchart: https://www.cs.missouristate.edu

**Next Steps:**
Meet with your advisor immediately to build a plan, as you still have all required Math courses to complete.

• **CS Electives:**
  • 9 hours
• **Other:**
  • Remaining GenEd, 120 total hours, and pass the MFT.

**Resources:**
Check the CS flowchart for the course sequence: https://www.cs.missouristate.edu

**Next Steps:**
Meet with your advisor to plan your remaining semesters.

instruction: I've passed CSC 130, CSC 131, and MTH 261. What's next and what's left for my degree?

Your remaining required courses for the major are:
• **Core CS:** CSC 232(4), CSC 244(3), CSC 325(3), CSC 333(2), CSC 335(3), CSC 360(3), CSC 365(3), CSC 388(3), CSC 450(4), CSC 482(2), CSC 565(3)
• **Math:** MTH 280(5), MTH 314(3), MTH 315(3), MTH 345(3) or MTH 540(3)
• **Science:** PHY 203(5) or 123(4), and BIO 121(4) or BMS 110(3)
• **CS Electives:** 9 hours
• **Other:** GenEd, 120 total hours, MFT.

**Resources:**
See the flowchart for the full path: https://www.cs.missouristate.edu

instruction: I have finished all the core Computer Science courses (from CSC 130 to CSC 565). What else do I need to graduate?

instruction: I just finished CSC 130. What other courses do I need for the CS degree?
response:
After completing CSC 130, you still need to complete the entire main sequence of the major.

• **Core CS:** CSC 131(4), CSC 232(4), CSC 244(3), CSC 325(3), CSC 333(2), CSC 335(3), CSC 360(3), CSC 365(3), CSC 388(3), CSC 450(4), CSC 482(2), CSC 565(3)
• **Math:** All 5 required math courses (MTH 261, 280, 314, 315, 345/540)
• **Science:** Both required science courses (Physics and Bio/BMS)
• **Electives:** 9 hours of CSC electives
• **Other:** GenEd, 120 total hours, MFT exam.

**Resources:**
See the full flowchart: https://www.cs.missouristate.edu

**Next Steps:**
Your next step is to take CSC 131 and your first math course.

instruction: I am done with CSC 130, 131, and 232. What are the remaining courses for my major?
response:
After completing CSC 130, 131, and 232, your remaining requirements for the major are:

• **Core CS:** CSC 244(3), CSC 325(3), CSC 333(2), CSC 335(3), CSC 360(3), CSC 365(3), CSC 388(3), CSC 450(4), CSC 482(2), CSC 565(3)
• **Math:** All 5 required math courses (MTH 261, 280, 314, 315, 345/540)
• **Science:** Both required science courses (Physics and Bio/BMS)
• **Electives:** 9 hours of CSC electives
• **Other:** GenEd, 120 total hours, MFT exam.

**Resources:**
See the full flowchart: https://www.cs.missouristate.edu

**Next Steps:**
Your next courses are CSC 244 (which also has CSC 131 as a prereq) and your foundational math courses.

instruction: I've completed all 100/200 level core CS and Math courses (CSC 130, 131, 232, 244, MTH 261, MTH 280). What 300+ level courses are left?
response:
If you have completed the 100/200 level core CS and Math, your remaining 300+ level requirements are:

• **Core CS:**
  • CSC 325(3), CSC 333(2), CSC 335(3), CSC 360(3), CSC 365(3), CSC 388(3), CSC 450(4), CSC 482(2), CSC 565(3)
• **Math:**
  • MTH 314(3), MTH 315(3), MTH 345(3) or MTH 540(3)
• **Science:**
  • PHY 203(5) or 123(4), BIO 121(4) or BMS 110(3)
• **Electives:**
  • 9 hours of CSC electives (most are 300+ level)
• **Other:**
  • GenEd, 120 total hours (ensure 40 are 300+), MFT exam.

**Resources:**
See the flowchart for course dependencies: https://www.cs.missouristate.edu

instruction: I am almost done with the core CS classes, only the 400 and 500-level ones are left. What are they, and what else do I need?

instruction: What are all the courses required to get a BS in Computer Science at Missouri State?
response:
To get a BS in Computer Science (CS Option), you must complete 120 total hours, including Core CS, Math, Science, and Elective courses.

**Core Computer Science (13 courses / 40 hours):**
• **CSC 130(3):** The World of Computer Science
• **CSC 131(4):** Computational Thinking
• **CSC 232(4):** Data Structures
• **CSC 244(3):** Computer Architecture
• **CSC 325(3):** Algorithms & Adv. Data Structures
• **CSC 333(2):** Lang. & Machines
• **CSC 335(3):** Database Systems Concepts
• **CSC 360(3):** Operating Systems
• **CSC 365(3):** Internet Programming
• **CSC 388(3):** Intro to Secure Computing
• **CSC 450(4):** Software Engineering
• **CSC 482(2):** Seminar in Computer Science
• **CSC 565(3):** Computer Networks

**Required Math (5 courses / 19 hours):**
• **MTH 261(5):** Calculus I
• **MTH 280(5):** Calculus II
• **MTH 314(3):** Discrete Mathematics
• **MTH 315(3):** Algebraic Structures
• **MTH 345(3) OR MTH 540(3):** Statistics OR Statistical Theory

**Required Science (2 courses):**
• **PHY 203(5) OR PHY 123(4):** Found. of Physics I OR Intro to Physics I
• **BIO 121(4) OR BMS 110(3):** (Biology or Biomedical Sciences)

**Other Requirements:**
• **9 hours** of approved CSC electives
• **General Education** courses
• **Exit Exam:** Pass the computer science major field test (MFT)

**Resources:**
Consult the official flowchart: https://www.cs.missouristate.edu

**Next Steps:**
This is a sample plan. You must meet with an advisor to map out your full remaining schedule and track your 120 total hours.

metadata.topic: BS Computer Science All Course Requirements (Missouri State)

response:
Here are the 13 core Computer Science (CSC) courses required for the BS in Computer Science (Computer Science Option):

• **CSC 130(3):** The World of Computer Science
• **CSC 131(4):** Computational Thinking
• **CSC 232(4):** Data Structures
• **CSC 244(3):** Computer Architecture
• **CSC 325(3):** Algorithms & Adv. Data Structures
• **CSC 333(2):** Lang. & Machines
• **CSC 335(3):** Database Systems Concepts
• **CSC 360(3):** Operating Systems
• **CSC 365(3):** Internet Programming
• **CSC 388(3):** Intro to Secure Computing
• **CSC 450(4):** Software Engineering
• **CSC 482(2):** Seminar in Computer Science
• **CSC 565(3):** Computer Networks

**Resources:**
These courses are all listed on the official department flowchart: https://www.cs.missouristate.edu

**Next Steps:**
Remember that in addition to these 40 hours of core courses, you also need 9 hours of CSC electives, plus all Math, Science, and General Education requirements.

metadata.topic: BS Computer Science Core CSC Courses (Missouri State)

instruction: How many courses and credit hours do I need for the Computer Science major at Missouri State?
response:
You need a total of **120 credit hours** to graduate. The requirements for the Computer Science Option are broken down as follows:

• **Core CS:** 13 courses (totaling 40 credit hours)
• **Math:** 5 courses (totaling 19 credit hours)
• **Science:** 2 courses (totaling 7-9 credit hours)
• **CS Electives:** 9 credit hours (usually 3 courses)
• **General Education & Minor:** The remaining hours (approx. 45-47) are filled by your General Education requirements and a minor (the Math courses often fulfill the minor).

**Graduation Requirements:**
• **Total Hours:** 120
• **Upper-Division:** At least 40 hours must be 300-level or above.
• **Exit Exam:** You must pass the Major Field Test (MFT) with a 50th percentile or higher.

**Resources:**
See the official flowchart for the visual breakdown: https://www.cs.missouristate.edu

**Next Steps:**
Use your C-APP degree audit in My Missouri State to track your progress toward these 120 hours.

metadata.topic: BS Computer Science Credit Hour Breakdown (Missouri State)

instruction: What are the math and science requirements for the BS in Computer Science at MSU?
response:
The BS in Computer Science has a strong math emphasis. You are required to complete the following 5 math courses and 2 science courses:

**Mathematics Requirements (5 courses):**
• **MTH 261(5):** Calculus I
• **MTH 280(5):** Calculus II
• **MTH 314(3):** Discrete Mathematics
• **MTH 315(3):** Algebraic Structures
• **MTH 345(3) OR MTH 540(3):** Statistics OR Statistical Theory

**Science Requirements (2 courses):**
• **Physics:** PHY 203(5) Found. of Physics I OR PHY 123(4) Intro to Physics I
• **Life Science:** BIO 121(4) OR BMS 110(3)

**Resources:**
These are listed on the official CS department flowchart: https://www.cs.missouristate.edu

**Next Steps:**
Be sure to check the prerequisites for these courses. For example, MTH 261 is a prerequisite for MTH 280, and MTH 315 is a prerequisite for CSC 325.

metadata.topic: BS Computer Science Math and Science Requirements (Missouri State)

instruction: Can you give me a checklist of all requirements to graduate with a BS in Computer Science from Missouri State?
response:
Yes, here is a checklist of the main requirements for the BS in Computer Science (Computer Science Option).

**Graduation Checklist:**
• **Total Hours:** Complete at least 120 total credit hours.
• **Upper-Division Hours:** Complete at least 40 credit hours at the 300-level or above.
• **Core CS:** Complete all 13 required core CSC courses (CSC 130 through CSC 565).
• **Math:** Complete all 5 required MTH courses (MTH 261, 280, 314, 315, and 345/540).
• **Science:** Complete 1 Physics course and 1 Life Science course from the approved list.
• **Electives:** Complete 9 hours of approved CSC electives.
• **Minor:** Fulfill the requirements for a minor (the required math courses typically satisfy the Mathematics minor).
• **GenEd:** Complete all General Education requirements.
• **Exit Exam:** Pass the Computer Science Major Field Test (MFT) with at least a 50th percentile score.

**Resources:**
You can visualize these requirements on the CS flowchart: https://www.cs.missouristate.edu

**Next Steps:**
Use your C-APP degree audit on My Missouri State as your official checklist and meet with your advisor every semester to confirm you are on track.

metadata.topic: BS Computer Science Graduation Checklist (Missouri State)

instruction: Tell me about Computer Science Department.
response:
Undergraduate programs
Computer science (CS) is the study of computers and computational systems.
Computer scientists create systems – from video games and phones to cars and airplanes – that are correct, reliable and efficient.
Major
Use your creativity to solve problems. This major prepares you to work in computer/video
game design, software development, computer forensics and many other arenas.
Major
Unlock more than just numbers. Discover patterns, predict trends and make the world
smarter.
Enhance your degree with a certificate or minor
Tech knowledge is valuable in any career field.
Certificate
Explore how programs and software are made.
Minor
Learn to code and other computer science basics.
Minor
Discover how tiny bits of data can lead to big discoveries.
Graduate programs
Propel your career or pivot into new roles with practical skills and advanced knowledge.
Our master's programs can be completed in two years (four semesters) or less.

instruction: Tell me about Computer Science Major - Computer Science Department.
response:
Option areas: Specialize your CS degree
We have updated the curriculum of both tracks to the recommendations of CS educational policymakers, represented by the [ACM](https://www.acm.org/) and [IEEE](https://www.computer.org/) professional organizations.
Option
Focus on the technical aspects of software creation. This option is accredited by
the
[Computing Accreditation Commission of ABET](https://www.abet.org/accreditation/).Option
Earn a broader degree that covers the design, development and analysis of software.
Why major in computer science at MSU?
- Study a versatile subject – Get equipped to solve problems in many high-paying
[career paths](/Major/careers.htm). Computer science also pairs well with many minors. - Find accessible course options – Don't have a background in computer science? That's okay! Several of our courses have minimal prerequisites, if any.
- Match your degree with your interests – Design a focused plan in our accredited
[computer science option](/Major/Computer-Science-Option.htm). Or, choose from courses in computer science and other subjects, like management and psychology, in the[software development option](/Major/Software-Development-Option.htm).

instruction: Tell me about Software Development Option - Computer Science Major - Computer Science Department.
response:
Software Development Option
Power connective platforms
Contribute to the growth of technology.
Manage software systems to streamline processes in almost any industry.
Manage software systems to streamline processes in almost any industry.
Why take the software development option?
- Go beyond the computer screen – Build your computer science expertise while getting a foundation in other content areas. You'll follow the network of technology into science subjects (e.g. biology, geology, etc.) and non-science topics, like communication and management.
- Synchronize your area of study with a minor – Computer science is useful in many other subject areas, including math, business, cybersecurity, communication and psychology.
- Make cutting-edge advancements – Step into an evolving field and discover ways to drive progress in technology.
At Missouri State, you'll have access to
[facilities and labs](/facilities.htm)that will prepare you for success. - Deploy your knowledge in an optimal setting – Discover the latest technology tools and trends from
[accomplished faculty](/people.htm).

instruction: What are the key points about BS Four-Year Degree Plan: Computer Science/Computer Science Option (ABET Accredited)?
response:
Here are the important details about BS Four-Year Degree Plan: Computer Science/Computer Science Option (ABET Accredited):
• A minor or second major is required. The computer science option has courses that automatically meet the requirements for a minor in math. Talk with your advisor to determine which minor (or second major) is best for you.
• The computer science option can usually be completed in four years or eight semesters. You may be able to finish sooner if you've earned dual credit or transfer credit while in high school or at other universities.
• We recommend that you do not finish all of your general education courses before you start to take courses in computer science.
• Some computer science courses do require prerequisites in mathematics. So, it's important to meet with an advisor in the program before you schedule for your first semester or as soon as you think you might be interested in the computer science major.
• College preparatory exam scores in mathematics will determine if you will have to take additional courses in mathematics.
• Review the admission and program requirements for full details on completing your degree.

instruction: Tell me about the undergraduate programs in the Computer Science Department at Missouri State University.
response: The Computer Science Department offers several undergraduate programs, including a Bachelor of Science (BS) in Computer Science and a BS in Data Science. Computer Science focuses on creating correct, reliable, and efficient computational systems, preparing students for careers in software development, computer/video game design, and computer forensics. Data Science focuses on discovering patterns, predicting trends, and interpreting data.

instruction: What undergraduate degree options are available within the BS in Computer Science major at MSU?
response: The Bachelor of Science in Computer Science major offers two primary options: the Computer Science Option and the Software Development Option. The Computer Science Option is accredited and focuses on algorithms, data structures, programming languages, and basics in other sciences like math and physics.

instruction: What are the requirements for declaring the Computer Science major at Missouri State?
response: There are no formal admission requirements to declare the computer science major. You must be admitted to Missouri State University. Students should contact the Academic Advising and Transfer Center to declare or change their major to computer science before completing 60 credit hours.

instruction: What is the minor requirement for the BS in Computer Science major at MSU?
response: The Computer Science major requires you to declare a minor or a second major. If you pursue the Computer Science Option of the CS major, you will automatically complete the requirements for a minor in math.

instruction: What graduate programs are offered by the Computer Science Department at MSU?
response: The Computer Science Department offers a Master of Science (MS) in Computer Science, and a Master of Natural and Applied Sciences (MNAS) with a computer science emphasis. These master's programs can typically be completed in two years or less.

instruction: What are some of the graduate certificates offered by the Computer Science Department?
response: The Computer Science Department offers several graduate certificates, including: Data analysis in applied sciences, Data science, and Software engineering.

instruction: What advanced degrees and programs are available for the MNAS Computer Science Emphasis?
response: The MNAS Computer Science Emphasis can be completed in two years or sooner. Degree options include the Traditional MNAS (finished in two years if you have a bachelor's degree) and the Accelerated MNAS. Computer science can be the primary or secondary emphasis.

instruction: What is the contact information for the Computer Science Department at Missouri State University?
response: The Computer Science Department is located in Cheek Hall 203C. The main telephone number is 417-836-4157, and the general email address is ComputerScience@MissouriState.edu. The address is Missouri State University, Computer Science Department, 901 S. National Ave., Springfield, MO 65897.

instruction: What is the graduate program contact information for the Computer Science Department?
response: For information about the master's degree, you can email CSGradProgram@MissouriState.edu. The Graduate Coordinator is Dr. Lloyd A. Smith, who can be reached at 417-836-4834 or LloydSmith@MissouriState.edu.

instruction: What is the four-year plan for the Computer Science BS - Computer Science Option after transferring from MSU-West Plains?
response: This particular plan guides students who complete the Associate of Science in Computer Science at MSU-West Plains to the Bachelor of Science in Computer Science - Computer Science Option at MSU-Springfield. Major requirements include: CSC 130 (The World of Computer Science), CSC 131 (Computational Thinking), CSC 232 (Data Structures), CSC 244 (Computer Architecture), CSC 325 (Algorithms and Advanced Data Structures), CSC 333 (Languages and Machines), CSC 335 (Database System Concepts), CSC 360 (Operating Systems), CSC 388 (Introduction to Secure Computing), CSC 450 (Introduction to Software Engineering), CSC 482 (Seminar in Computer Science), and CSC 565 (Computer Networks).

metadata.topic: BS Computer Science Option Transfer Plan (MSU-WP to MSU)

instruction: What are the common CSC courses required for the BS in Computer Science - Computer Science Option in a transfer plan?
response: Courses required for the major include: CSC 130 (The World of Computer Science), CSC 131 (Computational Thinking), CSC 232 (Data Structures), CSC 244 (Computer Architecture), CSC 325 (Algorithms and Advanced Data Structures), CSC 333 (Languages and Machines), CSC 335 (Database System Concepts), CSC 360 (Operating Systems), CSC 388 (Introduction to Secure Computing), CSC 450 (Introduction to Software Engineering), CSC 482 (Seminar in Computer Science), and CSC 565 (Computer Networks). Students must earn a 'C' or better in CSC 232 and CSC 244.

metadata.topic: BS Computer Science Option Core Courses

instruction: What are the mathematics requirements for the Data Science major at MSU?
response: Required mathematics courses for the Data Science major include: MTH 261 (Analytic Geometry and Calculus I), MTH 280 (Analytic Geometry and Calculus II), MTH 302 (Multivariate Calculus), MTH 314 (Discrete Mathematics), MTH 315 (Introduction to Logic and Proof), MTH 333 (Linear Algebra), and MTH 345 (Statistics for Scientists and Engineers).

instruction: What are the core computer science courses that fulfill the Public Affairs Capstone Experience for the Data Science major?
response: The Public Affairs Capstone Experience for the Data Science major is fulfilled by the completion of CSC 330 (Introduction to Data Science) and CSC 335 (Database System Concepts).

instruction: What advanced courses are listed as options for the Data Science major?
response: Advanced courses listed as options for the Data Science major include: CSC 537 (Deep Learning), CSC 587 (Computing for Bioinformatics), and CSC 596 (Special Readings).

instruction: What degree options are available for the Master's Degree in Computer Science at MSU?
response: During the first semester, MS students select one of three degree option areas: Course-only Option, Project Option, or Thesis Option.

instruction: What undergraduate certificates are offered by the Computer Science Department?
response: The department offers an undergraduate certificate in Web programming.

instruction: What undergraduate minors are offered by the Computer Science Department?
response: The department offers a Minor in Computer Science and a Minor in Informatics.

instruction: What is the course description for CSC 130: The World of Computer Science at Missouri State University?
response: CSC 130 is an introduction to programming and computer science. Topics include data representation, algorithm design, and software development. Students learn a high-level language and use it to write programs. The course is suitable for non-majors, and concurrent enrollment in MTH 136, MTH 137, or MTH 138 is strongly suggested for Computer Science majors or minors. It is a 3-credit hour course.

instruction: What are the core topics and prerequisites for CSC 325: Algorithms and Advanced Data Structures at Missouri State University?
response: CSC 325 is a study of algorithms and advanced data structures. Topics covered include graphs, heaps, hashing, self-adjusting data structures, set representations, greedy algorithms, dynamic programming, and an introduction to NP-complete problems. The course emphasizes the study of efficiency and algorithm analysis. The prerequisite is a C grade or better in CSC 232 and MTH 314 or MTH 315. This is a 3-credit hour course and may be taught concurrently with CSC 611, but credit cannot be received for both.

instruction: What is the purpose of the Software Development Option in the BS Computer Science major at MSU?
response: The Software Development Option is designed to build computer science expertise while providing a foundation in other content areas, such as science subjects (e.g., biology, geology) and non-science topics (e.g., communication, management). This option allows students to synchronize their area of study with a minor in areas like math, business, cybersecurity, communication, or psychology.

instruction: How long does it typically take to complete the Software Development Option in the BS Computer Science major?
response: The Software Development Option within the Computer Science major can usually be completed in four years (or eight semesters), using the provided four-year plan as a guide.

instruction: What is the policy regarding combining general education and major-required courses for a Computer Science major at MSU?
response: The department recommends that students do not complete all general education courses first. Instead, students should take a mixture of general education and major-required courses to ensure they stay on track to graduate. Regular meetings with an advisor are recommended.

instruction: What are the grade and GPA requirements for graduation from Missouri State University's Computer Science major?
response: General university graduation requirements often include earning a minimum of 120 credit hours and a minimum of 40 credit hours in upper-division courses (300-level and higher). Additionally, for the College of Business, a student must earn a minimum of a 2.50 GPA in all upper-division (300+) College of Business business unit coursework taken at Missouri State University.

instruction: What are the common CSC course topics that focus on the interaction between humans and systems?
response: Courses focusing on the interaction between humans and technical systems cover principles and theories of how humans and systems interact in: traditional media, networked environments, social and mobile computing, virtual environments, and information appliances. These courses also cover principles and theories of usability and accessibility and approaches to design and evaluation.

instruction: What are the core upper-level courses offered for the Information Technology Application Development Track at MSU?
response: The core upper-level courses for the Application Development Track include: ITC 362 (Mobile App Development), ITC 366 (Introduction to .Net Development with C#), ITC 370 (Introduction to Web Development), ITC 466 (Advanced .Net Development with C#), ITC 475 (Advanced Web Development), and ITC 528 (Database Application Development with Oracle). Students must select four of these courses.

instruction: What is CSC 232: Data Structures?
response: CSC 232 is a 4-credit hour course and a continuation of CSC 131. It covers algorithm design, complexity analysis, abstract data types and encapsulation, basic data structures (stacks, queues, linked lists, binary trees), dynamic memory allocation, recursion, sorting and searching, and debugging techniques.

instruction: What are the prerequisites for CSC 232: Data Structures?
response: The prerequisites for CSC 232 are a 'C' or better in CSC 131, and concurrent enrollment or credit in MTH 261, MTH 314, MTH 315, or MTH 215.

instruction: How is the credit breakdown for CSC 232?
response: CSC 232 is a 4-credit hour course, typically comprising 3 lecture hours and 2 lab hours. It is offered in Fall and Spring semesters.

instruction: What are the course offerings for undergraduate Computer Science students?
response: Undergraduate Computer Science courses are typically offered at the 100-500 level. Graduate courses are numbered 600-999.

instruction: What is the first Student Learning Outcome (SLO) for MSU Computer Science students?
response: The first SLO is that students will attain an ability to apply knowledge of computing and mathematics appropriate to the discipline.

instruction: What is the SLO related to problem solving and requirements?
response: Students will attain an ability to analyze a problem, and identify and define the computing requirements appropriate to its solution.

instruction: What is the SLO related to system design and implementation?
response: Students will attain an ability to design, implement, and evaluate a computer-based system, process, component, or program to meet desired needs.

instruction: What is the SLO concerning teamwork?
response: Students will attain an ability to function effectively on teams to accomplish a common goal.

instruction: What is the SLO related to ethics and professional responsibility?
response: Students will attain an understanding of professional, ethical, legal, security and social issues and responsibilities.

instruction: What is the SLO regarding communication?
response: Students will attain an ability to communicate effectively with a range of audiences.

instruction: What is the SLO related to the global impact of computing?
response: Students will attain an ability to analyze the local and global impact of computing on individuals, organizations, and society.

instruction: What is the SLO related to continuous professional development?
response: Students will attain recognition of the need for an ability to engage in continuing professional development.

instruction: What is the SLO regarding tools and techniques?
response: Students will attain an ability to use current techniques, skills, and tools necessary for computing practice.

instruction: What is the SLO concerning theoretical foundations and design tradeoffs?
response: Students will attain an ability to apply mathematical foundations, algorithmic principles, and computer science theory in the modeling and design of computer-based systems in a way that demonstrates comprehension of the tradeoffs involved in design choices.

instruction: What is the final SLO related to software construction?
response: Students will attain an ability to apply design and development principles in the construction of software systems of varying complexity.

instruction: What are the 500-level Computer Science courses at Missouri State University?
response: The 500-level CSC courses include: CSC 500 (Hardware, Software, and Troubleshooting Personal Computers), CSC 505 (Web-Based Resources in Educational Settings), CSC 510 (Networking and Telecommunications in Educational Settings), CSC 515 (Advanced Internet Programming), and CSC 521 (Compiler Construction).

instruction: List more 500-level CSC courses offered.
response: More 500-level CSC courses are: CSC 525 (Computer Graphics), CSC 526 (Methods of Optimization), CSC 534 (Big Data Analytics), CSC 535 (Data Mining), and CSC 537 (Deep Learning).

instruction: What are the final 500-level CSC courses listed in the catalog?
response: The final 500-level CSC courses listed are: CSC 538 (Parallel and Distributed Computing), CSC 540 (Introduction to Artificial Intelligence), CSC 545 (Computer Speech, Music and Images), CSC 565 (Computer Networks), CSC 567 (Mobile Computing Applications), CSC 587 (Computing for Bioinformatics), CSC 590 (Advanced Topics in Computer Science), and CSC 596 (Special Readings).

instruction: What is CSC 540?
response: CSC 540 is the Introduction to Artificial Intelligence course.

instruction: What CSC course covers Mobile Computing Applications?
response: CSC 567 covers Mobile Computing Applications.

instruction: What is the Computer Science course related to Bioinformatics?
response: The Computer Science course related to Bioinformatics is CSC 587: Computing for Bioinformatics.

instruction: What are the core CSC courses required for the Software Development Option?
response: Core CSC courses include: CSC 130 (The World of Computer Science), CSC 131 (Computational Thinking), CSC 232 (Data Structures), CSC 244 (Computer Architecture), CSC 335 (Database Systems Concepts), CSC 360 (Operating Systems), CSC 365 (Internet Programming), CSC 388 (Intro to Secure Computing), CSC 450 (Software Engineering), CSC 455 (Software Assurance/Proj. Mgt.), CSC 482 (Seminar in Computer Science), and CSC 565 (Computer Networks).

metadata.topic: Software Development Option Core CSC Courses

instruction: What are the required Mathematics courses for the Software Development Option?
response: Required Mathematics courses include MTH 314 (Discrete Mathematics) and MTH 315 (Algebraic Structures). Students must choose two of these three core CSC courses: CSC 325, CSC 335, and CSC 360.

metadata.topic: Software Development Option Math and CSC Core Choice

instruction: How many elective hours are required in the Software Development Option, and what courses can be chosen?
response: Students must choose 12 hours of electives from a list of courses (CSC 300-level to 500-level). This list includes: CSC 300 (Service Learning in CS), CSC 325 (Algorithms & Adv. Data Structures), CSC 330 (Intro to Data Science), CSC 515 (Advanced Internet Programming), and CSC 540 (Intro. to Artificial Intelligence).

instruction: Are there any credit hour limits on certain elective courses for the Software Development Option?
response: Yes, no more than three hours can count from CSC 399 (Cooperative Education) and no more than three hours can count from CSC 596 (Special Readings) toward the 12 hours of electives.

instruction: Is a minor required for the BS Computer Science with a Software Development Option?
response: Yes, a MINOR IS REQUIRED for the Computer Science 'Software Development' Option.

instruction: How many total hours and upper-division hours are needed to graduate from the BS Computer Science program?
response: To graduate, at least 120 hours of courses must be taken, including at least 40 hours of courses numbered 300 and above.

instruction: What are the science courses available for the Software Development Option general education?
response: Science courses with a lab that can be chosen include: BIO 121 (4 hrs), BMS 110/BMS 111 (4 hrs), CHM 116 (4 hrs), CHM 160/161 (5 hrs), PHY 123 (4 hrs), and PHY 203 (5 hrs). At least one of the chosen courses must have a lab.

instruction: What General Education (GenEd) courses are recommended outside of science for the Software Development Option?
response: Other recommended GenEd courses include: ECO 163 (3 hrs), PSY 121 (3 hrs), and ENG 321 (3 hrs).

instruction: What is the specific purpose of the Software Development Option at MSU?
response: The Software Development Option prepares students to manage software systems to streamline processes in almost any industry. It provides a foundation in other content areas like science, communication, and management.

instruction: What is the learning goal for ITC 235: Computer Hardware and Operating Systems?
response: The learning goal (LG) for ITC 235 is to identify and explain core components of modern computer systems, and to install, configure, and troubleshoot operating systems (e.g., Windows, Linux) while applying basic system administration tasks.

instruction: What is the learning goal for ITC 260: Programming Logic and Design for Business?
response: The LG for ITC 260 is to develop structured algorithms using programming logic constructs such as sequence, selection, and iteration.

instruction: What is the learning goal for ITC 295: Database Management Systems Concepts and Design?
response: The LG for ITC 295 is to design normalized relational database schemas and to create and manage database queries, reports, and constraints to support business decision-making and data integrity.

instruction: What is the learning goal for ITC 388: Information Systems Analysis and Design?
response: The LG for ITC 388 is to apply systems development life cycle (SDLC) methods to analyze, model, and design business information systems and create system documentation.

instruction: What is the learning goal for ITC 330: Introduction to Networking?
response: The LG for ITC 330 is to describe the fundamental components and functions of computer networks, including the OSI and TCP/IP models, and to configure and troubleshoot basic network devices.

instruction: What is the learning goal for ITC 430: Advanced Networking?
response: The LG for ITC 430 is to design and implement complex network architectures incorporating VLANs, routing protocols, and access control measures, and to analyze network performance and security through monitoring tools, packet inspection, and policy-based management.

instruction: What is the learning goal for ITC 360: Fundamentals of Cybersecurity?
response: The LG for ITC 360 is for students to demonstrate knowledge of the foundational aspects of cybersecurity.

instruction: What is the learning goal for ITC 566: Web Application Security?
response: The LG for ITC 566 is for students to demonstrate knowledge of current theory and techniques for securing web applications.

instruction: What is the learning goal for ITC 565: Computer Forensics?
response: The LG for ITC 565 is for students to demonstrate knowledge of prescribed practices involved in forensic analysis of digital assets following an information security breach.

instruction: What is the learning goal for ITC 563: Introduction to Network Security?
response: The LG for ITC 563 is for students to demonstrate knowledge of current theory and techniques for securing enterprise IT infrastructure.

instruction: What is the goal of the Associate of Science in Computer Science at MSU-West Plains?
response: The goal of the A.S. in Computer Science at MSU-West Plains is to provide students with the knowledge, skills, and coursework required to successfully transfer to a computer science bachelor's degree program.

instruction: What skills are gained in the MSU-West Plains AS Computer Science program?
response: Students gain knowledge of programming languages such as Python and C++, problem analysis, solution design, data structures, and algorithms.

instruction: What is the mean annual salary for a Computer Scientist?
response: The mean annual salary for a Computer Scientist is $152,310.

instruction: What is the mean annual salary for a Software Developer?
response: The mean annual salary for a Software Developer is $144,570.

instruction: What are the general university learning outcomes assessed by MSU?
response: The university assesses General Education outcomes and Public Affairs outcomes. The academic experience is grounded in a general education curriculum that heavily draws from the liberal arts and sciences.

instruction: Which academic college at MSU houses the Computer Science department?
response: The Computer Science Department is typically located within the College of Natural and Applied Sciences.

Topics in Computer Science), and CSC 596 (Special Readings).

instruction: What is the course number for Introduction to Data Science, and is it an SDO elective?
response: The course is CSC 330 (Intro to Data Science), and it is available as a 3-credit hour elective for the Software Development Option.

instruction: What are the dual-listed Math/CSC elective options for the SDO?
response: The dual-listed elective options are CSC/MTH 421 (Numerical Analysis I) and CSC/MTH 422 (Numerical Analysis II), both 3-credit hour courses.

instruction: What are the business/communication courses a student in the SDO must choose from?
response: Students must choose one course from this group: MKT 350 (3 hrs), PSY 305 (3 hrs), MGT 340 (3 hrs), PSY 481 (3 hrs), or COM 315 (3 hrs).

instruction: Which course fulfills the Writing II requirement for the BS in Computer Science - Software Development option in the OTC transfer plan?
response: The course that fulfills the Writing II requirement is a Program Specific Course at OTC that is equivalent to ITC 266 (and CSC 131) at MSU.

instruction: What is ITC 583: Cloud Computing?
response: ITC 583 is a course in Cloud Computing available as part of the Information Technology Application Development Track.

instruction: What is ITC 535: Machine Learning?
response: ITC 535 is a course in Machine Learning available as part of the Information Technology Application Development Track.

instruction: Which ITC courses focus on advanced web and .Net development?
response: ITC 475 (Advanced Web Development) and ITC 466 (Advanced .Net Development with C#) are the advanced programming courses in this track.

instruction: What core business course is required in the Fifth semester (fall) of the IT Application Development track?
response: FIN 380 (Financial Management), MGT 340 (Principles of Management), and MKT 350 (Principles of Marketing) are all required in the fifth semester.

instruction: What course options are available for the cultural competence general education requirement in the Sixth semester (spring) of the IT Application Development track?
response: Options include ANT 100 (World Cultures), GRY 100 (World Regional Geography), IDS 297 (International Culture and Study Abroad), or REL 110 (World Religions).

metadata.topic: IT Application Development Sixth Semester (Cultural Competence)

instruction: What is the capstone/management course in the Eighth semester (spring) of the IT Application Development track?
response: MGT 487 (Strategic Management and Policy) is a required course in the eighth semester.

instruction: What are the GPA requirements for admission and graduation from the College of Business for IT majors?
response: For Admission to the College of Business (COB), students need a minimum 2.00 Missouri State GPA and a minimum 2.50 combined GPA to take upper-division COB courses. For Graduation, students must obtain a 2.50 GPA in all upper-division (300+) COB business unit coursework taken at Missouri State University.

instruction: What are the career preparation areas for the BS in Computer Science major?
response: The BS in Computer Science major prepares students for careers in computer/video game design, software development, computer forensics, and many other arenas.

instruction: What are the career outcomes for Computer Science graduates at MSU?
response: Computer Science graduates at MSU have a 100% job placement rate and high starting salaries.

instruction: What are the main study areas in the BS in Data Science major at MSU?
response: The BS in Data Science focuses on helping students discover patterns, predict trends, and make the world smarter through data.

instruction: What academic support services does the Computer Science Department offer?
response: The department offers Tutoring to enhance learning and Advisement for academic help and guidance.

instruction: What is the range of undergraduate course numbers at Missouri State University?
response: Undergraduate courses are generally numbered from 100-599.

instruction: Why should I choose the Software Development Option over the Computer Science Option?
response: The Software Development Option allows you to go beyond the computer screen by building computer science expertise while gaining a foundation in other areas like science (biology, geology) and non-science topics (communication, management). It is structured to help you synchronize your area of study with a minor in areas such as business or cybersecurity.

instruction: Tell me about the prerequisite and core topics for CSC 232.
response: CSC 232 is a 4-credit course focusing on a continuation of CSC 131. Prerequisites are a 'C' or better in CSC 131 and an appropriate math course (MTH 261, MTH 314, or MTH 315). Key topics include algorithm design, complexity analysis, linked lists, binary trees, recursion, and sorting and searching.

instruction: What does the student learning outcome for professional, ethical, and social issues entail?
response: Students are expected to attain an understanding of professional, ethical, legal, security and social issues and responsibilities. This also includes the ability to analyze the local and global impact of computing on individuals, organizations, and society.

instruction: What are the required ITC courses for the Application Development Track?
response: Required ITC courses on the sample schedule include: ITC 200 (Critical and Creative Thinking Using Information Technology), ITC 235 (Computer Hardware and Operating Systems), ITC 388 (Information Systems Analysis and Design), and ITC 429 (Applications of Current and Emerging Technologies in Business).

instruction: Which upper-level CSC elective is related to security?
response: CSC 388: Intro to Secure Computing is listed as a 3-credit hour elective option for the Software Development major.

instruction: If I want to study Machine Learning, what is the best 500-level course at MSU?
response: The best course would be CSC 537: Deep Learning, which is available as a 3-credit hour elective for the Software Development Option.

instruction: What is the expected student competency in terms of applying theory in systems design?
response: Students will attain an ability to apply mathematical foundations, algorithmic principles, and computer science theory in the modeling and design of computer-based systems in a way that demonstrates comprehension of the tradeoffs involved in design choices.

instruction: What two majors are offered by the Computer Science Department at MSU?
response: The two undergraduate majors offered are the Bachelor of Science (BS) in Computer Science and the BS in Data Science.

instruction: Who should I contact for more information about the Computer Science Department?
response: You can contact the Computer Science Department at Missouri State University by calling (417) 836-4157 or emailing ComputerScience@missouristate.edu. The department is located at 901 S. National, Springfield MO 65897.

instruction: What is the focus of the MS in Computer Science graduate degree?
response: The MS in Computer Science prepares students to be the architect of digital innovation.

instruction: What are the three track options for the Information Technology Undergraduate Program?
response: The three track options are: Application Development, Cybersecurity, and IT Infrastructure.
